description: Graded exercise testing (GET) is a common method of determining the effect of disease or disability on aerobic work capacity (AWC).GET is clinically useful for assessing exercise-related  health risk, for verifying the benefit of a medical or surgical intervention to improve AWC, and for prescribing exercise training intensity in a preventive or rehabilitative program. GET is used as an outcome measure of training in a wide range of patient populations and has been used to predict the length of recovery in pediatric patients post-concussion(5)

GET protocols have progressive stages that gradually increase exercise intensity on a treadmill (incline and speed) or cycle ergometer (resistance). Stages advance to a predetermined end point such as a target heart rate (HR), rating of perceived exertion (RPE), or to the patient’s AWC associated with volitional fatigue(1)

Onset of fatigue or other limiting signs and symptoms at an early stage of GET indicates low cardiorespiratory fitness, or peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak), that often corresponds to deficits in endurance for ADLs
Medical guidelines are the basis for safe and effective GET procedures(1)

HR, blood pressure (BP), and RPE should always be monitored during GET. Optional respiratory gas collection to calculate VO2peak enhances individualized exercise prescription and provides the gold-standard  measurement of cardiorespiratory fitness. However, VO2peak is more often estimated from the oxygen (O2) requirement of the highest stage or work rate reached on a standard GET protocol(1)

Diagnostic GET may include additional noninvasive monitoring (e.g., ECG, oximeter, pulmonary function tests). Such “exercise stress testing” of patients with known or symptomatic cardiac or pulmonary diseases should be conducted in specialty clinics with physician supervision and emergency rescue equipment.(1) This Clinical Review focuses on GET of patients without suspected heart or lung disease and consequently with average exercise-related  cardiopulmonary risk for age
indications: Evaluation of medical or surgical intervention to improve physical functioning
Assessment of exercise-related  risk of symptoms
Exercise prescription for a preventive or rehabilitative exercise program (such as for patients with cardiac, pulmonary, or metabolic disease)
To rule out cardiorespiratory limitations to functional aerobic capacity

Document coexisting conditions or other symptoms that may complicate exercise, such as muscle atrophy, poor balance, or history of falls. Document any symptoms that may indicate need for referral to physician, such as cognitive or neurological deficits. Are there coexisting movement problems such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, muscular dystrophy, or Parkinson’s disease? Is there a history of obesity, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, hypertension, or pulmonary disease? Comorbidities may limit standard participation; however, GET appears to be safe and useful for determining exercise capacity in individuals with mild deficits within 14 days post stroke or transient ischemic attack(6)

relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for and proper use of ambulatory assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess both static and dynamic standing balance, as well as unilateral balance. If full weight-bearing (FWB), assess balance in standing on each leg, walking on toes, and timed single-leg  stand. Observe for deficits in hip strategies in an effort to maintain balance. Use Berg Balance Scale (BBS), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Testing may be indicated to establish patient’s ability for treadmill GET. Assess walking agility, including tandem gait and turns. Note ability to change directions while walking. Assess gait safety with the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Scan functional strength of the lower and upper extremities with manual muscle testing (MMT)Assess pain with V AS
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess general posture and lower extremity alignment, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Scan functional ROM and flexibility of the upper and lower extremities

other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Clinicians should follow the exercise testing guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Rehabilitation clinicians should always use their professional judgment regarding the prescription of exercise based on the results of GET

treatment summary: Conduct the GET according to established guidelines.(1) To maintain safety and effectiveness, a physician, nurse, clinical exercise physiologist, or physical therapist with special training should administer the exercise test and write the exercise prescription
Select the GET protocol appropriate for the patient and laboratory setting

The following is a common submaximal cycle ergometer GET protocol for general screening and cardiorespiratory fitness testing that can be used for most patient populations –Position the patient properly on the ergometer –Allow the patient 2–3 minutes of warm-up  at a low work rate such as 150 kilogram-meters  per minute (kgm/min), which is a resistance setting of 0.5 on a 6 meters per revolution flywheel with 50 revolutions per minute pedaling rate –The protocol consists of 3-minute  stages, starting at 300 kgm/min and increasing by 150 kgm/min or 300 kgm/min, as appropriate for the patient –Record HR, BP, and RPE in the second and third minute of each stage. The stage can be increased to the next level provided HR and BP do not show large increases in the third minute(indicating a cardiovascular plateau), BP remains normal, and RPE is not “very hard” –The target end point is typically 85%APMHR. The test should be stopped if the patient cannot maintain the required pedal frequency, indicates volitional fatigue, or experiences shortness of breath. Other reasons to terminate the test include systolic BP exceeding 260 mm Hg or systolic BP dropping more than 20 mm Hg despite continuing exercise –After GET, the patient should cool down while pedaling with no or minimal resistance until feeling recovered and systolic BP returns to the level during warm-up –The patient should remain in the clinic under observation until any exercise-related  symptoms resolve

In maximal GET that uses a standard treadmill or cycle ergometer protocol, the O2 requirement of the final stage that the patient completed can be taken from a nomogram or calculated with a metabolic equation. This value can be considered the patient’s predicted VO2peak(1)

In submaximal GET that uses a standard treadmill or cycle ergometer protocol, the O2 requirement of each stage that the patient completed can be taken from a nomogram or estimated with a metabolic equation. A “best fit” line is drawn to connect the O2 requirement (x-axis)  and the observed HR (y-axis)  for each stage and extrapolated to the patient’s APMHR for prediction of VO2peak

The stages of GET can also be regulated by the patient’s RPE ›See Description and Indications of device/equipment and Guidelines for use of device/equipment above  .
